title: Eponyms Quiz
description: Discover words that come from people's names!

questions.question: The word 'sandwich' is named after which historical figure?
questions.explanation: The sandwich is named after John Montagu, the 4th Earl of Sandwich (1718-1792). Legend has it he asked for meat between two slices of bread so he could eat without leaving the card table.

questions.question: Which scientist gave their name to the unit of temperature 'Fahrenheit'?
questions.explanation: Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit (1686-1736) was a Polish-German physicist who invented the mercury thermometer and developed the Fahrenheit temperature scale.

questions.question: The word 'pasteurize' comes from which famous scientist?
questions.explanation: Pasteurization is named after French chemist Louis Pasteur (1822-1895), who developed the process of heating liquids to kill harmful bacteria, making milk and other beverages safer to drink.

questions.question: Braille, the tactile writing system for the blind, is named after whom?
questions.explanation: Braille is named after Louis Braille (1809-1852), a Frenchman who lost his sight as a child and developed the raised-dot reading and writing system at age 15.

questions.question: The word 'diesel' (as in diesel engine) comes from whom?
questions.explanation: The diesel engine is named after Rudolf Diesel (1858-1913), a German engineer who invented a more efficient internal combustion engine that used compression ignition rather than spark plugs.

questions.question: The word 'boycott' comes from a person named Captain Boycott. What was he?
questions.explanation: Captain Charles Boycott (1832-1897) was a land agent in Ireland whose tenants refused to deal with him in 1880 over unfair rents. Their organized shunning of him gave English the word 'boycott.'

questions.question: Which military leader's name gave us the word 'sideburns'?
questions.explanation: Sideburns are named after American Civil War General Ambrose Burnside (1824-1881), who wore distinctive thick strips of facial hair. Originally called 'burnsides,' the syllables were later reversed.

questions.question: The word 'saxophone' is named after which person?
questions.explanation: The saxophone was invented by and named after Adolphe Sax (1814-1894), a Belgian instrument maker who patented the instrument in 1846.

questions.question: The word 'nicotine' is derived from whose name?
questions.explanation: Nicotine is named after Jean Nicot (1530-1604), the French ambassador to Portugal who introduced tobacco to the French court and promoted it as a medicine.

questions.question: The leotard garment is named after whom?
questions.explanation: The leotard is named after Jules Leotard (1838-1870), a French acrobat and trapeze artist who developed the one-piece, skin-tight garment to give himself more freedom of movement during performances.

questions.question: The word 'shrapnel' is named after which person?
questions.explanation: Shrapnel is named after General Henry Shrapnel (1761-1842), a British Army officer who invented an artillery shell designed to burst in mid-air and scatter metal fragments over a wide area.

questions.question: The word 'maverick' (meaning independent-minded person) comes from whom?
options: A Texas rancher who didn't brand his cattle
questions.explanation: Maverick comes from Samuel Maverick (1803-1870), a Texas rancher who refused to brand his cattle. His unbranded calves became known as 'mavericks,' and the word came to mean anyone who goes their own way.

questions.question: The word 'cardigan' (the sweater) is named after whom?
questions.explanation: The cardigan is named after James Brudenell, the 7th Earl of Cardigan (1797-1868), who led the Charge of the Light Brigade. He reportedly wore a knitted waistcoat to keep warm during the Crimean War.

questions.question: The word 'mesmerize' comes from which historical figure?
questions.explanation: Mesmerize comes from Franz Anton Mesmer (1734-1815), a German physician who believed in 'animal magnetism' â€” that an invisible force could be used to heal. His techniques were a precursor to hypnosis.

questions.question: The word 'dunce' (meaning a slow learner) ironically comes from the name of whom?
questions.explanation: Dunce comes from John Duns Scotus (1266-1308), a brilliant medieval theologian and philosopher. When his followers resisted new ideas during the Renaissance, they were mockingly called 'Dunses' or 'dunces.'
